elements.content: Four novel compounds {[In­(FDA)­(HFDA)­(H2O)4]­·2H2O} (In1) and {[Ln2(FDA)2­(H2O)10]­·FDA­·6H2O} n (Ln = Dy2, Eu3, Gd4) have been hydrothermally synthesized by using the ligand furan-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2FDA). Driven by hydrogen bonding and π···π stacking, In1 displays a supramolecular metal–organic framework (MOF) with 6-connected pcu topology. Isostructural Dy2, Eu3, and Gd4 possess one-dimensional “wave-like” chains and further exhibit bnn topological structures with the Schläfli symbol of (46·64) via a hydrogen bonding network. The triplet state (T1 = 22371 cm–1) of H2FAD studied by compound Gd4 indicates that the energy transition from the H2FDA ligand to the Eu3+ ion in compound Eu3 is efficient but inefficient to the Dy3+ ion in compound Dy2. Interestingly, the uncoordinated carbonyl group of compound In1 can sensitize Ln3+ ions to obtain Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 materials for enhancing luminescence. The possible sensitization mechanism is studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and surface photovoltage spectroscopy. When the Eu3+ ion is increased from 0.0 to 1.6 μM in aqueous solution, compound In1 exhibits a distinguishable luminescence color change from blue to red with a fast detection time (<2 min), and the ratio of luminescence intensity at 617 nm to that at 408 nm (I 617/I 408) enhances linearly with a low detection limit of 0.87 μM. Additionally, with careful adjustment of lanthanide­(III) ions, white-light emission material could be achieved with metal content of Dy0.87Eu0.13.

elements.content:
The strategy of introducing lanthanide­(III) ions into metal−organic framework host structure expands a new path for preparing luminescence sensors and white-light emission material.

Introduction

Crystalline metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with structural periodicity and diversity have attracted extensive interest for a number of applications including adsorption and separation, selective catalysis, luminescence, selective cation exchange, sensing, and magnetism. The outstanding performances behind these applications usually rely on the predetermined functional groups that are present within the MOFs architectures. Porous MOFs provide enough space to introduce a guest molecule to the interior of the lattice, and the available functional group is active enough without destroying the MOF structure. Great success has been achieved in MOFs with amino, alkynyl, and sulfonic functional groups. For example, Gao et al. reported the postsynthetically created electron-deficient 2,2′-bipyridinium moieties in a Zr-MOF provide charge-transfer interacting sites for recognizing and capturing alkylamines with excellent selectivity. Xiang et al. incorporated TEEP-OH (thioether-enol phosphate, phenol substituted) into the phosphodiester backbone of G-quadruplex DNA by a facile postsynthetic method to achieve efficient photocaging of their activities. Notably, the MOFs with an uncoordinated carbonyl group have scarcely been reported. Meanwhile, the method of MOFs serving as a host framework to encapsulate guest molecules to fabricate luminescent materials is attractive for practical application.
elements.clean_text:
The strategy of introducing lanthanide(III) ions into metal-organic framework host structure expands a new path for preparing luminescence sensors and white-light emission material.

Introduction

Crystalline metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with structural periodicity and diversity have attracted extensive interest for a number of applications including adsorption and separation, selective catalysis, luminescence, selective cation exchange, sensing, and magnetism. The outstanding performances behind these applications usually rely on the predetermined functional groups that are present within the MOFs architectures. Porous MOFs provide enough space to introduce a guest molecule to the interior of the lattice, and the available functional group is active enough without destroying the MOF structure. Great success has been achieved in MOFs with amino, alkynyl, and sulfonic functional groups. For example, Gao et al. reported the postsynthetically created electron-deficient 2,2'-bipyridinium moieties in a Zr-MOF provide charge-transfer interacting sites for recognizing and capturing alkylamines with excellent selectivity. Xiang et al. incorporated TEEP-OH (thioether-enol phosphate, phenol substituted) into the phosphodiester backbone of G-quadruplex DNA by a facile postsynthetic method to achieve efficient photocaging of their activities. Notably, the MOFs with an uncoordinated carbonyl group have scarcely been reported. Meanwhile, the method of MOFs serving as a host framework to encapsulate guest molecules to fabricate luminescent materials is attractive for practical application.

elements.content: Stimulated by the coordinating ability between carbonyl groups and metal ions, luminescent lanthanide­(III) ions are the high-profile candidate for guest chromophores because of its narrow emission band, large Stokes shift, high luminescence efficiency, and long luminescence lifetime. Note that the luminescence intensities of lanthanide­(III) ions are generally restricted by an aqueous environment, which decreases photons emitted by discrete molecules and leads to low quantum yield. Undoubtedly, MOFs possess some advantages to sensitize lanthanide­(III) ions. First, MOFs could offer a rigid scaffold to avoid the influence of solvent quenching for lanthanide­(III) ions and further modulate the luminescence properties of lanthanide­(III) ions. Second, MOFs possess a well-organized structure to incorporate a mass of lanthanide­(III) ions to enhance detection sensitivity. Thus, introducing lanthanide­(III) ions into a MOFs host structure furnishes an effective strategy to obtain tunable luminescence and fabricates luminescence sensing material. In particular, luminescent assemblies of molecules that can be tuned for white-light emission are of great importance due to the potential applications. Currently, many research studies are devoted to develop white-light emission materials; for example, Tian group has designed and synthesized a novel colorful-emission host–guest complex BPCY, which could generate nearly pure white-light emission with CIE coordinates (0.33, 0.34). Snaith and his co-workers blended perovskite crystals with different emission wavelengths in a polymer host to replicate natural white light. Lan group realized white light emission by a stable mesoporous blue-emitting MOF NENU-521 as a host for encapsulating Alq3. Seeking for more environmentally friendly and higher efficiency white-light emission material is urgent and necessary. With judiciously chosen green-(Dy3+) and red-(Eu3+) ions encapsulated in MOFs matrixes, host–guest materials with white-light emission could be realized.

elements.content: On the basis of the above consideration, we propose an effective method to generate luminescent MOFs, which can apply in aqueous solution and white-light emission. There are four novel compounds, namely, {[In­(FDA)­(HFDA)­(H2O)4]­·2H2O} (In1), {[Ln2(FDA)2­(H2O)10]­·FDA­·6H2O} n (Ln = Dy2, Eu3, Gd4) (H2FDA = furan-2,5-dicarboxylic acid). Compound In1 displays a 6-connected pcu topological network, while isostructural Dy2, Eu3, and Gd4 possess bnn topological structures with the Schläfli symbol of (46·64). The structure of Eu3 has been reported by Akerboom et al., but they take more time (several weeks) to grow a single crystal than that of our method (only taking 5 days). Herein as compared, compound Eu3 is included in the discussion in order to provide powerful evidence that the method of sensitization Ln3+ ions could effectively enhance luminescence. The triplet state (T1 = 22371 cm–1) of H2FAD studied by compound Gd4 indicates that the energy transition from H2FDA ligand to the Eu3+ ion in compound Eu3 is efficient but inefficient to the Dy3+ ion in compound Dy2. Interestingly, the uncoordinated carbonyl group of compound In1 can sensitize Ln3+ ions to obtain Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 materials for enhancing luminescence (). Surface photovoltage spectroscopy (SPS) reveals the photogenerated charges behavior of the materials to further illustrate the sensitization mechanism. With increasing the Eu3+ ion from 0.0 to 1.6 μM in aqueous solution, compound In1 displays rapidly detection capacity (<2 min), and the ratio of luminescence intensity at 617 nm to that at 408 nm (I 617/I 408) enhances linearly with a low detection limit of 0.87 μM. Meanwhile, simple control of Dy3+ and Eu3+ reactant stoichiometry in compound In1 allows for dichromatic fine-tuning in a linear fashion to correlate the emission intensities, Ln3+ ions compositions, and chromaticity coordinates. In this way, we obtain white-light emission material with metal content of Dy0.87Eu0.13.

Compound In1 displays a 6-connected  pcu  topological network, while isostructural Dy2, Eu3, and Gd4 possess  bnn  topological structures with the Schläfli symbol of (46⋅64). The structure of Eu3 has been reported by Akerboom et al., but they take more time (several weeks) to grow a single crystal than that of our method (only taking 5 days). Herein as compared, compound Eu3 is included in the discussion in order to provide powerful evidence that the method of sensitization Ln3+ ions could effectively enhance luminescence. The triplet state (T1 = 22371 cm-1) of H2FAD studied by compound Gd4 indicates that the energy transition from H2FDA ligand to the Eu3+ ion in compound Eu3 is efficient but inefficient to the Dy3+ ion in compound Dy2. Interestingly, the uncoordinated carbonyl group of compound In1 can sensitize Ln3+ ions to obtain Dy  3+  @In1 and Eu  3+  @In1 materials for enhancing luminescence (). Surface photovoltage spectroscopy (SPS) reveals the photogenerated charges behavior of the materials to further illustrate the sensitization mechanism. With increasing the Eu3+ ion from 0.0 to 1.6 μM in aqueous solution, compound In1 displays rapidly detection capacity (<2 min), and the ratio of luminescence intensity at 617 nm to that at 408 nm (I 617/I 408) enhances linearly with a low detection limit of 0.87 μM. Experimental Section

Synthesis of {[In(FDA)(HFDA)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} (In1)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.0603 g, 0.20 mmol) and H2FDA (0.0157 g, 0.1 mmol) is dissolved in 6 mL of distilled H2O with pH = 3.8 by addition of NaOH. After stirring for 0.5 h in air, it is heated (120 °C) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 120 h. After subsequent slow cooling, block crystals are obtained and washed with distilled H2O (yield 63.2% based on H2FDA). Elemental analysis calcd for [C12H15O15In (M r : 532.08)]: C, 28.04; H, 2.94%; found: C, 28.03.; H, 2.96%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3219 (br), 1717 (s), 1625 (vs), 1569 (s), 1393 (s), 1347 (s), 1217 (m), 1180 (w), 1022 (m), 966 (m), 836 (w), 771 (m), 604 (m), 475 (w), 419 (w) (Figure S5).

After stirring for 0.5 h in air, it is heated (120 °C) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 120 h. elements.content: Compound In1 (100 mg) is immersed in aqueous nitrate salts solution of Dy3+, Eu3+ (0.1 mol/L), and Dy3+/Eu3+ (0.1 mol/L), respectively, for 48 h. Subsequently, the samples are washed with distilled water to remove redundant Ln3+ ions on the surface. On the other hand, compound In1 (100 mg) is immersed in aqueous solution of Eu­(NO3)3 with different concentrations: from 10–2 to 10–7 mol/L to yield stable colloidal dispersions.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Ln3+ @In1 

Compound In1 (100 mg) is immersed in aqueous nitrate salts solution of Dy3+, Eu3+ (0.1 mol/L), and Dy3+/Eu3+ (0.1 mol/L), respectively, for 48 h. Subsequently, the samples are washed with distilled water to remove redundant Ln3+ ions on the surface. On the other hand, compound In1 (100 mg) is immersed in aqueous solution of Eu(NO3)3 with different concentrations: from 10-2 to 10-7 mol/L to yield stable colloidal dispersions.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated In1 has crystallized in the monoclinic crystal system with space group Pc (). There are one In­(III) ion, two H2FDA ligands, four coordinated H2O molecules, and two free H2O molecules in the asymmetry unit. Metal In­(III) center is six-coordinated to two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two H2FDA ligands and four oxygen atoms from four coordinated H2O molecules, forming a octahedron geometry (Figure S1). All the In–O bond lengths as well as the bond angles are within the normal ranges found in other In­(III) ion compounds. Upon carefully observation of the structure, there exists an extensive hydrogen bonding network which helps connect adjacent discrete monomers to create a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture. The mononuclear units are linked through O9–H9A···O5 hydrogen bonding to generate one-dimensional (1D) chains (a), for which the H···O distance is 1.763 Å. The O13–H13B···O4 hydrogen bonding interaction links 1D chains to form two-dimensional (2D) layers in the ac plane [d(H13B···O4) = 1.896 Å], as shown in b. The two-dimensional layers are further linked through O14–H14A···O10 hydrogen bonding interaction (the distance of H14A···O10 is 2.329 Å), constructing a 3D supermolecular framework (c). Moreover, the interlayer π···π stacking interaction with the distance of 3.503 Å makes the framework more stable. If the metal is viewed as the node and the H2FDA ligand as the linker, the whole framework could be reduced to a 6-connected pcu topological network (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of {[In(FDA)(HFDA)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} (In1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated In1 has crystallized in the monoclinic crystal system with space group Pc (). There are one In(III) ion, two H2FDA ligands, four coordinated H2O molecules, and two free H2O molecules in the asymmetry unit. Metal In(III) center is six-coordinated to two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two H2FDA ligands and four oxygen atoms from four coordinated H2O molecules, forming a octahedron geometry (Figure S1). All the In-O bond lengths as well as the bond angles are within the normal ranges found in other In(III) ion compounds. Upon carefully observation of the structure, there exists an extensive hydrogen bonding network which helps connect adjacent discrete monomers to create a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture. The mononuclear units are linked through O9-H9A⋅⋅⋅O5 hydrogen bonding to generate one-dimensional (1D) chains (a), for which the H⋅⋅⋅O distance is 1.763 Å. The O13-H13B⋅⋅⋅O4 hydrogen bonding interaction links 1D chains to form two-dimensional (2D) layers in the ac plane [d(H13B⋅⋅⋅O4) = 1.896 Å], as shown in b. The two-dimensional layers are further linked through O14-H14A⋅⋅⋅O10 hydrogen bonding interaction (the distance of H14A⋅⋅⋅O10 is 2.329 Å), constructing a 3D supermolecular framework (c). Moreover, the interlayer π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interaction with the distance of 3.503 Å makes the framework more stable. If the metal is viewed as the node and the H2FDA ligand as the linker, the whole framework could be reduced to a 6-connected  pcu  topological network (d).

elements.content: Compound In1 showing (a) 1D chain through O–H···O interactions; (b) 2D layers through O–H···O interactions; (c) 3D supramolecular framework of In1; (d) topological representation of 3D structure.

Considering that compounds Dy2, Eu3, Gd4 are isostructural, we choose Dy2 to represent the detailed structure. Compound Dy2 has crystallized in the triclinic crystal system space group of P1̅, and its asymmetric unit contains two Dy­(III) ions, two FDA2– anions, 10 coordinated H2O molecules, one free FDA2– anions, and six free H2O molecules. As shown in Figure S2, the central Dy­(III) ion is nine-coordinated in a slightly distorted monocapped square antiprism through four oxygen atoms from two FDA2– anions and five oxygen atoms from five coordination H2O molecules. The bond lengths of Dy–O are in the range of 2.373(6)–2.587(6) Å, and bond angles of O–Dy–O vary from 51.75(2) to 147.1(2)°, which all correspond to those reported for other Dy­(III) compounds. Neighboring Dy­(III) ions share common FDA2– ligands to generate 1D “wave-like” chains (a). Through O22–H22B···O7, O24–H24A···O10, and O21–H21A···O8 hydrogen bonding interactions, neighboring chains are interconnected to produce 2D layers in the bc plane, for which the distances of H···O are 2.003, 2.363, and 2.649 Å, respectively (b,c). With the help of FDA2– and coordinated H2O molecules, the 2D layers can be further joined to a 3D supramolecular framework (d) by hydrogen bonding interactions (O23–H23A···O14 = 2.152 Å, O23–H23B···O14 = 2.229 Å, and O19–H19A···O11= 2.255 Å) and exhibit a 5-connected bnn topological structure with the Schläfli symbol of (46·64) (e). The PLATON calculation shows the overall channel value without solvent molecules equal to 347.5 Å3, approximately counting for 19.6% of the total volume of 1777.3 Å3.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of {[Ln2(FDA)2(H2O)10]⋅FDA⋅6H2O} n  (Ln = Dy2, Eu3, and Gd4)

Considering that compounds Dy2, Eu3, Gd4 are isostructural, we choose Dy2 to represent the detailed structure. Compound Dy2 has crystallized in the triclinic crystal system space group of P1̅, and its asymmetric unit contains two Dy(III) ions, two FDA2- anions, 10 coordinated H2O molecules, one free FDA2- anions, and six free H2O molecules. As shown in Figure S2, the central Dy(III) ion is nine-coordinated in a slightly distorted monocapped square antiprism through four oxygen atoms from two FDA2- anions and five oxygen atoms from five coordination H2O molecules. The bond lengths of Dy-O are in the range of 2.373(6)-2.587(6) Å, and bond angles of O-Dy-O vary from 51.75(2) to 147.1(2)°, which all correspond to those reported for other Dy(III) compounds. Neighboring Dy(III) ions share common FDA2- ligands to generate 1D "wave-like" chains (a). Through O22-H22B⋅⋅⋅O7, O24-H24A⋅⋅⋅O10, and O21-H21A⋅⋅⋅O8 hydrogen bonding interactions, neighboring chains are interconnected to produce 2D layers in the bc plane, for which the distances of H⋅⋅⋅O are 2.003, 2.363, and 2.649 Å, respectively (b,c). With the help of FDA2- and coordinated H2O molecules, the 2D layers can be further joined to a 3D supramolecular framework (d) by hydrogen bonding interactions (O23-H23A⋅⋅⋅O14 = 2.152 Å, O23-H23B⋅⋅⋅O14 = 2.229 Å, and O19-H19A⋅⋅⋅O11= 2.255 Å) and exhibit a 5-connected  bnn  topological structure with the Schläfli symbol of (46⋅64) (e). The PLATON calculation shows the overall channel value without solvent molecules equal to 347.5 Å3, approximately counting for 19.6% of the total volume of 1777.3 Å3.

elements.content: To study the energy transfer process in detail, it is important to investigate the electronic states of H2FDA. It is well-known that the Gd­(III) compound is the best choice for calculating the triplet energy levels of H2FDA ligand due to following two reasons: (1) The Gd3+ ion increases the intersystem crossing rate due to its heavy atom effect. (2) The Gd3+ ion’s first excited-state electronic level is at high energy (6P7/2 at around 32150 cm–1), and there is no Gd3+ ion emission ranging from 200 to 800 nm. The observed luminescence emission derives from the ligand of the Gd­(III) compound. Therefore, the main energy transfer pathway is the radiative decay process. The triplet excited state (T1) for the H2FDA ligand (22371 cm–1, 447 nm) is estimated by the phosphorescence spectrum of compound Gd4 (a). The singlet energy level (S1) for H2FDA ligand is 30121 cm–1 (332 nm; b), calculating from the UV–vis absorbance edge. It is known that when the value about ΔE(S1 – T1) of H2FDA ligand is calculated over 5000 cm–1 raised by Reinhoudt, the intersystem crossing (ISC) process will be efficient. Thus, the ΔE(S1 – T1) of H2FDA ligand is 7750 cm–1, indicating the ISC process will run smoothly.
elements.clean_text:
Energy Transfer Process

To study the energy transfer process in detail, it is important to investigate the electronic states of H2FDA. It is well-known that the Gd(III) compound is the best choice for calculating the triplet energy levels of H2FDA ligand due to following two reasons: (1) The Gd3+ ion increases the intersystem crossing rate due to its heavy atom effect. (2) The Gd3+ ion's first excited-state electronic level is at high energy (6P7/2 at around 32150 cm-1), and there is no Gd3+ ion emission ranging from 200 to 800 nm. The observed luminescence emission derives from the ligand of the Gd(III) compound. Therefore, the main energy transfer pathway is the radiative decay process. The triplet excited state (T1) for the H2FDA ligand (22371 cm-1, 447 nm) is estimated by the phosphorescence spectrum of compound Gd4 (a). The singlet energy level (S1) for H2FDA ligand is 30121 cm-1 (332 nm; b), calculating from the UV-vis absorbance edge. It is known that when the value about ΔE(S1 - T1) of H2FDA ligand is calculated over 5000 cm-1 raised by Reinhoudt, the intersystem crossing (ISC) process will be efficient. Thus, the ΔE(S1 - T1) of H2FDA ligand is 7750 cm-1, indicating the ISC process will run smoothly.

elements.content: As depicted in Scheme S1, there are the energy levels about triplet state (T1) of the H2FDA ligand and resonant energy states of Dy3+ (4F9/2, 21000 cm–1) and Eu3+ (5D1, 19000 cm–1). On the basis of Latva’s empirical rule, optimized energy transfer process for Ln3+ requests ΔE(T1 – 4F J ) = 2500–4500 cm–1 for Dy3+ and ΔE(T1 – 5D J ) = 2500–4000 cm–1 for Eu3+. The calculated value of ΔE(T1 – 4F J ) for Dy3+ is 1371 cm–1, and the calculated value of ΔE(T1 – 5D J ) for Eu3+ is 3371 cm–1. Thus, the transition from triplet state of H2FDA to Dy3+ ion in compound Dy2 is inefficient but efficient to Eu3+ ion in compound Eu3. What needs to be explained is the nonradiative relaxation from the 5D1 to 5D0 energy state becomes effective because of the absent bands from 5D1 to ground state in Eu­(III) compounds.

elements.content: The solid state luminescence properties of compounds In1, Dy2, and Eu3 are studied at room temperature (298 K). As shown in a,b, the emission spectrum of compound In1 exhibits an intense blue luminescent emission at 408 nm, whose Commission Internacionale d’Eclairage (CIE) coordinate is 0.17, 0.09. The similar shape of the emission band with the free H2FDA ligand indicates that the luminescence of compound In1 originated from the ligand and the slight redshift might be ascribed to the coordination of the H2FDA ligand with the metal center. In addition, compounds Dy2 and Eu3 are also highly luminescent and display their typical characteristic transitions (c,d).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid state luminescence properties of compounds In1, Dy2, and Eu3 are studied at room temperature (298 K). As shown in a,b, the emission spectrum of compound In1 exhibits an intense blue luminescent emission at 408 nm, whose Commission Internacionale d'Eclairage (CIE) coordinate is 0.17, 0.09. The similar shape of the emission band with the free H2FDA ligand indicates that the luminescence of compound In1 originated from the ligand and the slight redshift might be ascribed to the coordination of the H2FDA ligand with the metal center. In addition, compounds Dy2 and Eu3 are also highly luminescent and display their typical characteristic transitions (c,d).

elements.content: On the basis of the feature of containing uncoordinated carbonyl groups, compound In1 prompts us to employ it as a host for encapsulating and sensitizing Ln3+ ions for tunable luminescence in an aqueous environment. In an initial attempt, compound In1 was immersed in aqueous media containing different Ln­(NO3)3 (Ln3+ = Dy3+ and Eu3+) to generate lanthanide­(III) ion-encapsulated materials, Ln 3+ @In1. As expected, compound In1 acts as a host and successfully protects Ln3+ ions from aqueous quenching; meanwhile, the luminescence property of Ln 3+ @In1 is significantly affected by Ln3+ ions. The emission spectrum of Dy 3+ @In1 emits a typical Dy3+ ion emission at λem = 477, 574, and 662 nm (λex = 315 nm, a) and is ascribed to the characteristic emission transitions of Dy3+ (4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, and 4F9/2 → 6H11/2). In addition, the characteristic emission of In1 at λem = 408 still exist. On the other hand, the emission spectrum of Eu 3+ @In1 emits its representative emission peaks at λem = 594, 617, 652, and 695 nm originated from encapsulated Eu3+ ion and is assigned to the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1–4) transitions: 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4, whereas the emission peak at 408 nm is attributed to the energy transition from the In1 to the Eu3+ center (b). The ligand-centered emission in Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 is decreased, indicating there exists an antenna effect, namely, energy transition following by ISC process S1 → T1 and T1 → f transition and f–f emission of Ln3+ ions. The ICP measurements performed on the final Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 materials reveal the doped amounts of Dy3+ and Eu3+ are up to 23.38 and 22.21% of In1, respectively. The molar ratio of In3+/Ln3+ is about 1:1 and suggests that one Ln3+ ion appropriately matches one uncoordinated carbonyl group in the structure of In1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S4) and infrared (IR) spectra (Figure S5) of the Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 confirm the structure of In1 still maintain the host framework after encapsulating Ln3+ ions.

elements.content: Luminescent lifetimes of Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 are also measured at 298 K (c,d). It is noteworthy that the Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1 show the long Ln3+ lifetimes compared to that of individual In1, Dy2, and Eu3 (τ = 18.62 μs for the Dy 3+ @In1; τ = 418.79 μs for the Eu 3+ @In1; τ = 7.63 μs for the In1; τ = 7.85 μs for the Dy2; τ = 339.25 μs for the Eu3). This could be explained as the effective energy transition between the Ln3+ ions and compound In1 (Figure S6). These results indicate that compound In1 not only provides sufficient protection to Ln3+ ions as host in an aqueous environment, but also sensitizes Ln3+ ions with efficient energy transfer for Dy3+ and Eu3+.

elements.content: In order to further illustrate the sensitization mechanism affected by the uncoordinated carbonyl groups, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies of O 1s were performed on In1, Dy 3+ @In1, and Eu 3+ @In1. The O 1s peak from free oxygen atoms at 530.85 eV in In1 is moved to 531.35 and 531.59 eV after encapsulating Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions, respectively (a), indicating the formation of the weak bond between oxygen atoms and Ln3+ ions in Ln 3+ @In1, which results in the change of the electron energy level of ligand, and the energy transfer occurs between In1 and Ln3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Possible Sensitization Mechanism

In order to further illustrate the sensitization mechanism affected by the uncoordinated carbonyl groups, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies of O 1s were performed on In1, Dy  3+  @In1, and Eu  3+  @In1. The O 1s peak from free oxygen atoms at 530.85 eV in In1 is moved to 531.35 and 531.59 eV after encapsulating Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions, respectively (a), indicating the formation of the weak bond between oxygen atoms and Ln3+ ions in Ln  3+  @In1, which results in the change of the electron energy level of ligand, and the energy transfer occurs between In1 and Ln3+ ions.

elements.content: For compounds In1, Dy 3+ @In1, and Eu 3+ @In1 surface photovoltage spectroscopy (SPS) was also used to investigate the photogenerated charge behavior of the materials. As shown in b, compound In1 displays a positive photovoltage response at 318 nm. The electrons (e–) are excited and transferred from valence band (VB) to conduction band (CB), and the holes (h+) are left in VB. The e– and h+ transfer to the opposite direction and lead to photovoltage signal. After the encapsulation of Ln3+ ions, the SPS intensities are reduced significantly, which reveals a small number of e– were separated, and the others participated in this sensitization process of Ln 3+ @In1. Because the energy level of the CB of compound In1 is higher than Dy3+ and Eu3+, the e– could move to the energy level of Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions (). Meanwhile, the h+ tends to move to the 4f energy level, which leads to enhanced luminescence emission by the radiative transition process. Therefore, Dy3+and Eu3+ ions could serve as a recombination center to facilitate electron transition from compound In1 to Ln3+ ions. It should be noted that there are differences about the SPS response between Dy 3+ @In1 and Eu 3+ @In1, which is ascribed to the energy level match degree of Ln3+ ions and compound In1. In a word, the SPS result offers an effective test to sensitize Ln3+ ions within compound In1.

elements.content: Sensitivity is a key factor in evaluating a sensor. a,b shows the luminescence changes of In1 in various concentrations of Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution. These Eu3+ loaded materials display obviously naked eye visible emission (with UV lamp excitation). The representative Eu3+ ion emission bands are observed at 10–7 mol L–1 for In1. With the successive increase of the Eu3+ ion, the intensity of the blue emission peak at 408 nm (I 408) gradually decreases, and the red emission peaks at 617 nm (I 617) show continuous enhancement (c). The relative ratios (I 617/I 408) were calculated based on the data shown in d. Figure 7e plots the dependence of I 617/I 408 on the Eu3+ ion in the range of 0.0–1.0 μM and is expressed as I 617/I 408 = 10.16C Eu 3+ – 0.432 (where R 2 = 0.991), implying that In1 is an excellent ratiometric luminescent sensor for the quantitative analysis of the Eu3+ ion. The limit of detection for the Eu3+ ion is as low as 0.87 μM, calculated as 3σ/m (Table S5), where σ is the standard deviation for five replicating detections of the blank and m is the slope of the calibration curve.

Ratiometric Ln3+ Ion Sensing

Sensitivity is a key factor in evaluating a sensor. a,b shows the luminescence changes of In1 in various concentrations of Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution. These Eu3+ loaded materials display obviously naked eye visible emission (with UV lamp excitation). The representative Eu3+ ion emission bands are observed at 10-7 mol L-1 for In1. With the successive increase of the Eu3+ ion, the intensity of the blue emission peak at 408 nm (I 408) gradually decreases, and the red emission peaks at 617 nm (I 617) show continuous enhancement (c). The relative ratios (I 617/I 408) were calculated based on the data shown in d. Figure 7e plots the dependence of I 617/I 408 on the Eu3+ ion in the range of 0.0-1.0 μM and is expressed as I 617/I 408 = 10.16C Eu 3+ - 0.432 (where R 2 = 0.991), implying that In1 is an excellent ratiometric luminescent sensor for the quantitative analysis of the Eu3+ ion. The limit of detection for the Eu3+ ion is as low as 0.87 μM, calculated as 3σ/m (Table S5), where σ is the standard deviation for five replicating detections of the blank and m is the slope of the calibration curve.

elements.content: To further investigate the time-response rate of this ratiometric luminescent sensor, the luminescence intensity of Eu 3+ @In1 at 617 nm (λex = 315 nm) was measured at different times in aqueous solution. As shown in Figure S7, with increasing interaction time, more and more Eu3+ ions interact with oxygen atoms, and the luminescence intensities of these samples are continuously enhanced. When compound In1 is treated with the Eu3+ ions for 2 min, the emission peak at 617 nm obviously increases, which reveals that is a fast Eu3+-induced luminescence enhancement response. Meanwhile, this sensing process is approved by the PXRD analyses. The PXRD patterns of the samples for 2 min and 48 h are almost identical with that of compound In1 (Figure S4), demonstrating that the whole skeleton of the In1 crystal is not changed, although the luminescent intensity is largely increased. Undoubtedly, the low-detection limit and fast respond time demonstrate that compound In1 is a suitable ratiometric luminescence sensor for practical applications.

elements.content: On the basis of green emitted by Dy3+ ion and red emitted by Eu3+ ion, herein we expected to integrate different ratios of Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions into a single-crystal of mixed-In1 system. Generally with a combination of green and red with blue luminescence, white-light emission materials could be realized. To evaluate the effect, the samples of Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 were prepared and their luminescent properties were studied. The resulting products exhibit their multiband emission. The emission peaks at 478 and 576 nm are attributed to the transitions of Dy 3+ (4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, respectively), the emission peaks at 592, 617, and 698 nm are ascribed to the transitions of Eu 3+ (5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F4), and broad emission peak at 408 nm are attributed to energy transition of In1 (a). Upon gradually increasing the ratios of Eu3+ ion, the red-emission shows continuous enhancement, while that of green emission decreases accordingly. This enables color tuning in the RG spectral region simply by changing the metal ratios in the single crystal (b). Luminescent lifetimes of the Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 samples were also measured (λex = 315 nm, λem = 575 nm (Dy3+) and 617 (Eu3+), respectively). As shown in Table S6, the Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 sample is systematically biexponential, which reveals that there are two distinct lanthanide­(III) ions in the framework of In1. With increasing the Eu3+ ion ratios, the lifetimes of Eu3+ emissions increase, and a decrease in the lifetimes of Dy3+ emissions is observed, which strongly indicates an energy transfer process might exist in this material. As seen from c,d, the emission colors and the chromaticity coordinates in the CIE diagram can be systematically tuned with precise correlation to the Dy3+/Eu3+ ratios. The good linear fitting curves between luminescence intensity and Eu3+ metal content, Eu3+ metal content, and CIE-X values have been obtained and are expressed as y = 34890x + 537.7, where R 2 = 0.994 and y = 1.91x – 0.5, where R 2 = 0.992, respectively.

Upon gradually increasing the ratios of Eu3+ ion, the red-emission shows continuous enhancement, while that of green emission decreases accordingly. This enables color tuning in the RG spectral region simply by changing the metal ratios in the single crystal (b). Luminescent lifetimes of the Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 samples were also measured (λex = 315 nm, λem = 575 nm (Dy3+) and 617 (Eu3+), respectively). As shown in Table S6, the Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 sample is systematically biexponential, which reveals that there are two distinct lanthanide(III) ions in the framework of In1. With increasing the Eu3+ ion ratios, the lifetimes of Eu3+ emissions increase, and a decrease in the lifetimes of Dy3+ emissions is observed, which strongly indicates an energy transfer process might exist in this material. As seen from c,d, the emission colors and the chromaticity coordinates in the CIE diagram can be systematically tuned with precise correlation to the Dy3+/Eu3+ ratios. The good linear fitting curves between luminescence intensity and Eu3+ metal content, Eu3+ metal content, and CIE-X values have been obtained and are expressed as y = 34890x + 537.7, where R 2 = 0.994 and y = 1.91x - 0.5, where R 2 = 0.992, respectively.

elements.content: The linear correlation established for these Dy3+/Eu3+-codoped In1 samples not only proves the validity of emission fine-tuning among RG color through a dichromatic approach but also provides a useful tool to accurately determine the CIE coordinates from their metal compositions, which could be used as a guide to predict the synthetic conditions. As demonstrated in , with the help of linear correlation, we can conveniently prepare white-light emission material at CIE coordinates (0.33, 0.33) with metal content of Dy0.87Eu0.13. In other words, the linear correlation can easily tell us how to prepare a compound that emits a specific color by mixing different metal ions.

elements.content: In summary, an effective strategy has been demonstrated to generate novel materials with luminescence sensing and white-light emission by uncoordinated carbonyl groups encapsulating Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions into metal–organic compound In1. The sensitization mechanism investigated by the XPS and SPS technology indicates that Ln3+ ions could serve as a recombination center to facilitate electron transfer from compound In1 to Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions. As increasing Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution, the dual luminescence change of compound In1 leads to a novel and visual colorimetric sensor for the Eu3+ ion with a low detection limit (0.87 μM) and fast detection time (<2 min). Encapsulating green Dy3+ and red Eu3+ into compound In1, we also succeed in precise control of dichromatic color-tuning, establishing correlation equations for wide range color tunability useful for synthetic prediction and obtaining white-light emission material with metal content of Dy0.87Eu0.13. This work expands a new path for preparing luminescence sensors and white-light emission material.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, an effective strategy has been demonstrated to generate novel materials with luminescence sensing and white-light emission by uncoordinated carbonyl groups encapsulating Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions into metal-organic compound In1. The sensitization mechanism investigated by the XPS and SPS technology indicates that Ln3+ ions could serve as a recombination center to facilitate electron transfer from compound In1 to Dy3+ and Eu3+ ions. As increasing Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution, the dual luminescence change of compound In1 leads to a novel and visual colorimetric sensor for the Eu3+ ion with a low detection limit (0.87 μM) and fast detection time (<2 min). Encapsulating green Dy3+ and red Eu3+ into compound In1, we also succeed in precise control of dichromatic color-tuning, establishing correlation equations for wide range color tunability useful for synthetic prediction and obtaining white-light emission material with metal content of Dy0.87Eu0.13. This work expands a new path for preparing luminescence sensors and white-light emission material.

A mixture of In­(NO3)3 (0.0603 g, 0.20 mmol) and H2FDA (0.0157 g, 0.1 mmol) is dissolved in 6 mL of distilled H2O with pH = 3.8 by addition of NaOH. After stirring for 0.5 h in air, it is heated (120 °C) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 120 h. After subsequent slow cooling, block crystals are obtained and washed with distilled H2O (yield 63.2% based on H2FDA). Elemental analysis calcd for [C12H15O15In (M r : 532.08)]: C, 28.04; H, 2.94%; found: C, 28.03.; H, 2.96%. The synthesis method of Gd4 is also alike to that of Dy2, except Gd­(NO3)3­·6H2O instead of Dy­(NO3)3­·6H2O. Colorless block crystals are obtained (yield 53.6% based on H2FDA). Elemental analysis calcd for [C18H38Gd2O31 (1064.98)]: C, 20.30; H, 3.60%; found: C, 20.28 H, 3.61%. cln_elements.content:
The solid state luminescence properties of compounds In1, Dy2, and Eu3 are studied at room temperature (298 K). As shown in a,b, the emission spectrum of compound In1 exhibits an intense blue luminescent emission at 408 nm, whose Commission Internacionale d’Eclairage (CIE) coordinate is 0.17, 0.09. The similar shape of the emission band with the free H2FDA ligand indicates that the luminescence of compound In1 originated from the ligand and the slight redshift might be ascribed to the coordination of the H2FDA ligand with the metal center. In addition, compounds Dy2 and Eu3 are also highly luminescent and display their typical characteristic transitions (c,d).

Ratiometric Ln<sup>3+</sup> Ion Sensing

Sensitivity is a key factor in evaluating a sensor. a,b shows the luminescence changes of In1 in various concentrations of Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution. These Eu3+ loaded materials display obviously naked eye visible emission (with UV lamp excitation). The representative Eu3+ ion emission bands are observed at 10–7 mol L–1 for In1. With the successive increase of the Eu3+ ion, the intensity of the blue emission peak at 408 nm (I 408) gradually decreases, and the red emission peaks at 617 nm (I 617) show continuous enhancement (c). The relative ratios (I 617/I 408) were calculated based on the data shown in d. Figure 7e plots the dependence of I 617/I 408 on the Eu3+ ion in the range of 0.0–1.0 μM and is expressed as I 617/I 408 = 10.16C Eu 3+ – 0.432 (where R 2 = 0.991), implying that In1 is an excellent ratiometric luminescent sensor for the quantitative analysis of the Eu3+ ion. The limit of detection for the Eu3+ ion is as low as 0.87 μM, calculated as 3σ/m (Table S5), where σ is the standard deviation for five replicating detections of the blank and m is the slope of the calibration curve.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid state luminescence properties of compounds In1, Dy2, and Eu3 are studied at room temperature (298 K). As shown in a,b, the emission spectrum of compound In1 exhibits an intense blue luminescent emission at 408 nm, whose Commission Internacionale d'Eclairage (CIE) coordinate is 0.17, 0.09. The similar shape of the emission band with the free H2FDA ligand indicates that the luminescence of compound In1 originated from the ligand and the slight redshift might be ascribed to the coordination of the H2FDA ligand with the metal center. In addition, compounds Dy2 and Eu3 are also highly luminescent and display their typical characteristic transitions (c,d).

Ratiometric Ln3+ Ion Sensing

Sensitivity is a key factor in evaluating a sensor. a,b shows the luminescence changes of In1 in various concentrations of Eu3+ ion in aqueous solution. These Eu3+ loaded materials display obviously naked eye visible emission (with UV lamp excitation). The representative Eu3+ ion emission bands are observed at 10-7 mol L-1 for In1. With the successive increase of the Eu3+ ion, the intensity of the blue emission peak at 408 nm (I 408) gradually decreases, and the red emission peaks at 617 nm (I 617) show continuous enhancement (c). The relative ratios (I 617/I 408) were calculated based on the data shown in d. Figure 7e plots the dependence of I 617/I 408 on the Eu3+ ion in the range of 0.0-1.0 μM and is expressed as I 617/I 408 = 10.16C Eu 3+ - 0.432 (where R 2 = 0.991), implying that In1 is an excellent ratiometric luminescent sensor for the quantitative analysis of the Eu3+ ion. The limit of detection for the Eu3+ ion is as low as 0.87 μM, calculated as 3σ/m (Table S5), where σ is the standard deviation for five replicating detections of the blank and m is the slope of the calibration curve.
